Robert Lehman Collection: Renaissance to Impressionism

description: The present pair of vases is thought to have been made in the eighteenth century, although a later date had also been suggested.(1) The current dating is based on similarities to other eighteenth-century works, including a hexagonal garniture (ca. 1760 – 75), published in 2008 by Aronson, which also features polychrome chinoiserie decoration,(2) and an Imari jar of nearly identical form in the collection of the Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire, Brussels.(3)  Blue and white covered vases of the same form can also be seen as part of a garniture published in 2011 by Aronson.(4) Catalogue entry from Elizabeth Sullivan. The Robert Collection. Decorative Arts, Volume XV. Wolfram Koeppe, et al. The Metropolitan Museum of Art in association with Princeton University Press, 2012, p. 171.NOTES:1. I am indebted to Jeffrey Munger for his observations on the Lehman vases.2. Aronson, Robert D. Dutch Delftware, including Selections from the Collection of Dr. F. H. Fentener van Vlissingen and a Rare Group of I. W. Hoppesteyn Marked Objects. Amsterdam, 2008, no. 91.3. Helbig, Jean. Faiences hollandaises, XIIe, XVIIIe, début XIXe s. 2 vols. Musees Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire. Brussels, n.d. [after 1950], vol. 1, fig. 93.4. Aronson, Robert D. Ed. In the Eye of the Beholder: Perspectives on Dutch Delftware. Amsterdam, 2011, no. 38.
provenance: Norden sale, American Art Association, Anderson Galleries, New York, 18-19 January 1935, lot 39.  Acquired by Robert Lehman from the Norden sale.
title: Covered Jar, polychrome floral decoration, handle on cover in shape of squirrel.
